title: Do you need to include 401k, IRA(retirement) and expected tax refund under your exemptions on chp13 bankruptcy? pls advise
question: I'm in CA and in a midst of working with an attorney and filling out paperworks. There is this form about exemptions which ask about assets stuffs and 401k/IRA and tax refunds, etc. Do I really need to include all of these in that form? If so, why? For 401k/IRA, I can just look up statements. But for expected tax refund, I'm not sure if how much refund I will be getting this year since I just started paying my mortgage this year(since Jan). I may not get any refund at all since I am claiming exemptions=9(both fed/state) in my paystubs.The whole of last year, I didn't pay my mortgage due to paycut/etc so I didn't get any tax refund at all.Please advise CA attorney on how to handle this. Thanks in advance..
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Bankruptcy exemptions,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Retirement benefits and ERISA
answers:
You can try paycheckcity.com as way to estimate tax refunds. Because you are deducting the taxes that you pay, you must add back in the amount to be refunded. Regarding the rest, you must list everything you own or are entitled to. Anything less is fraud. The good news is that your 401K is protected by a federal law known as ERISA.

The number one rule in bankruptcy is disclosure.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

You need to disclose ALL of your assets and ALL of your liabilities in a bankruptcy petition.

I would not attempt to handle your own chapter 13. Doing so is like stitching your own wound. Seek competent bankruptcy counsel.

You only need to list these assets if you care about facing charges of Bankruptcy fraud and losing these assets!

If you don't list the asset & claim the exemption, you can't keep the asset. It's just that simple!

As to the tax refund, most people are in a similar situation, the refund is different each year. Just take a guess that is as high as you could imagine it to be. That will be adequate.
